Posts.Content: May 31, 2009 09:48AM - edited May 31, 2009 09:49AM by dkhancock1948 Lursa: How are you today?!  Hope you are taking it easy. Jayne:  I didn't think about being bald and excessive facial hair, either.  That brought a laugh!  My hair is actually back in, maybe 1/2 inch all over.  One of the most awesome feelings I have ever had is feeling the wind blow my hair.  I never thought about before it happened about a month ago.  It was wonderful!  It was like God was telling me to be joyful in the little things.  If I could have jumped, I would have.  It was such a wonderful feeling.   Donnid:  Do you mean shaving your face?  Hopefully, this will go away like they say some of the other symptoms will.  I love it when you are told that the symptoms will go away or they may be permanent. No guarantees.  Does anyone know if a person can eat something to give more energy?  How is exercise supposed to help you get energy?  I never had a lot of energy before cancer, but it was a whole lot more than I have now.  Won't it be great when we get our lives back!!!  Whole new outlooks on everything! Debbie
Posts.Title: May 2009 surgery lovinmomma dkhancock1948

Posts.Content: May 25, 2009 03:32PM dkhancock1948 wrote: I was diagnosed on 11-12-2008 with ILC.  I had 8 chemo treatments starting 12-5-08.  I had a couple of delays in my treatment schedule because of insurance, but that was resolved.  Two days after my last chemo - 3-19 - shingles came out of my left side from my cleavage area around to my spine.  My surgeon postponed my surgery from April to May 19th.  I had a mastectomy last Tueday with two lymph nodes removed on my left side.  I have two drains in.  My husband died 11-23-2006, so I am on my own most of the time.  My son lives with me, but works full time.  My daughter lives a block behind me, but has her own family and job.  Thank goodness, I was able to work during chemo - just really slow walking.  Taxol gave me neuropathy of my feet and left hand - mainly thumb and finger tips.  Shingles left a pain around my shoulder blade to let me know it was there.  My surgery was on Tuesday and I came home Wednesday.  My daughter helped me do my drains the first time, but after that I can do them.  I was allowed to take a shower 48 hours after surgery with the drains in.  I had a shower chair, but didn't need to use it.  I wash what little hair I have with my right hand.  Things I wish I knew I would have trouble with - opening anything that needs to be unscrewed.  I didn't realize that even using the hand and arm on the side that wasn't operated on makes you use the other side.  I was used to being very independent, and it is really hard not being able to do the things that need to be done.  My husband was my best friend, so I really didn't cultivate close relationships with other women.  I have found out that I hate not having anyone to talk with during the day. I wished I had found this site before.  I would have stocked up on more TV dinners that I could have fixed easily.   It is amazing to read everything.  I heart goes out to all of you.  My prayers.  I just want my life to be the way it was.  Sometimes I feel like such a baby.  I have gotten so that I don't want anymore blood taken out.  I almost cried when the nurse came in last Tuesday evening telling me she needed to take blood.  After the third time, she found a good vien.  The other two she tried started and then stopped letting the blood come out.  I can't believe chemo messes up your veins they way it does. I am to call my surgeon's office tomorrow to let them know about the drainage.  I have other questions to ask to see if it is normal or not.  The swelling has went down a lot, but I still have tenderness and a little redness where it is hallow now (if that makes sense).  I have no idea how much drainage is normal (realizing it will be different for everyone).  I think I am having phantom pain from time to time where the shingles made my nipple extra sensitive.  I was expecting to feel normal now and I now know that was a little unrealistic.  I have staples across my left side and steri-strips on top of the staples.  I feel like I have an extra tight bra on. I am so thankful for this site.  I feel like I have a family I can talk with and see if what I am going through is the same as someone else.  Thank you for letting me spout off.  My feelings also go all over the place - confusion, depression, self-pitying.  And yes, after surgery, you have the complete feeling - it's gone.
Posts.Title: May 2009 surgery lovinmomma dkhancock1948

Posts.Content: May 31, 2009 09:53AM dkhancock1948 wrote: Kimberly:  I was just reading some of the posts and read where you had a bilateral mastectomy and a hysterectomy the same day.  Wow!  How are you doing?  Debbie
Posts.Title: May 2009 surgery lovinmomma dkhancock1948

Posts.Content: May 29, 2009 04:51PM dkhancock1948 wrote: Lursa - thank you for your kind words.  Sorry I didn't respond earlier, but I have been having a real pity-party and wasn't positive enough to even put a line down.  I don't like feeling like this, but I have been this past week.  You are one strong, strong lady.  I apprecite your comments! Thank you for all the other comments. As with you others, I can't believe I have breast cancer either.  No one in my family has ever had breast cancer.  My aunt (Mother's sister had colon cancer when she was 80 and is still going strong at 85).  My aunt was fortunate and didn't have to have chemo. When my husband retired December 2004, so did the insurance.  He tried to get social security disability, got it in 10-2006 and then died on Thanksgiving 2006.  I had graduated from college when I was 54 with a degree to teach elementary with an endorsement to teach kindergarten.  Never got a permanent job until this year, six years later.  When I was talking to the insurance person about the type of account you take money out before taxes to use of medical items, I told the man, I NEVER get sick, so I didn't need to have much taken out.  Famous last words!  My insurance went into effect 10-1-2008.  I thought fall break would be a good time to start getting check since I hadn't since 2004.  On October 31st, I had my first mammorgram, with my doctor calling me up on November 4th to say I needed a 2nd mammogram.  I can't believe all the pills you have to take.  I was not one  to get side effects, but I sure did when I was on chemo with the pills I took. I still have two drains in, one could have come out today, but I would have needed to drive 1 1/2 hours one way to my doctor's office.  It is hard to find someone to drive you with a half-hours notice.  I am to call back on Monday.  Hopefully the second drain will be able to come out.  My doctor says it has to be under 25 ccs from each drain.  The second drain is putting out around 30 ccs right now. I am glad to know that others have weird feelings.  I never expected any of this.  I still have pain from where the shingles were on my back.  I know we will finally get our lives back, but sometimes I start wondering when. My pity party is really the fact that I am alone.  My son has already went to his fiance for the weekend.  I know right now that unless I get any phone calls, I will have absolutely no one to talk with.  I think throughout this whole ordeal, that has been the worst part.  I have found out what lonely is.  I really never knew it until now.  Things will be so much different when the tubes are out and I can drive. Again, thank you to whomever started these discussion groups.  Even though I am not talking in person with any of you, this helps so much.  I feel like I am a part of a huge family.  It's good to know you are not the only one going through these different feelings and pains. Debbie
Posts.Title: May 2009 surgery lovinmomma dkhancock1948

Posts.Content: May 29, 2009 07:49PM - edited May 29, 2009 07:52PM by dkhancock1948 I have a question.  This really sounds weird, but after chemo and when all your hair starts growing back in, did you get excessive facial hair?  A month after chemo, all my eyebrows fell out and then they came in the next week.  My eyelashes had already fallen out at least two months before my eyebrows and were back in.  I have had hairs on my chin for some time and the older I get, the more chin hairs I get.  BUT, my chin hairs are coming in quite abundantly and facial hair on my cheeks is noticeable now.  Did anyone else have this?  I had a complete hysterectomy in May 1990.  My body hair diminished a lot where I only needed to shave my legs and underarms about once a month, which was really nice.  The hairs on my arms left.  Now I notice I have hair back on my arms.  I wonder if I will have to start shaving my legs again. :( Ha. The ups and downs of chemo.  What do you do with facial hair when it is very noticeable?  Have a good weekend.  Debbie
Posts.Title: May 2009 surgery lovinmomma dkhancock1948

Posts.Content: May 30, 2009 05:14PM dkhancock1948 wrote: Lursa:  WOW!!!  Good things you listened to your instincts.  Was this caused from the drain being pulled out?  Had it been bleeding since the surgery?  Thank goodness your DH was there!  Did you get to stay overnight?  What an experience!  Glad you are back home.  Just take care!  Debbie
Posts.Title: May 2009 surgery lovinmomma dkhancock1948

Posts.Content: Jun 12, 2009 07:05PM - edited Jun 13, 2009 06:16PM by dkhancock1948 Hi all!  I have a question.  Does it take a while for the tenderness to go away after the drainage tubes and staples come out after surgery?  About how long? Debbie
Posts.Title: May 2009 surgery lovinmomma dkhancock1948

Posts.Content: Jun 3, 2009 01:08PM dkhancock1948 wrote: Hi to all!  I was surprised last evening, my DS stayed and took the lasagna out.  He left as soon as he took it out.  One thing that I still have trouble with is asking for help.  I do ask for help, but probably not as much as I should.  I was always the strong and independent one.  Now the physical side of me has changed, but not completely my attitude.  I have learned through this, I don't want to be alone the rest of my life.  Hopefully, when I am ready, I can find at least a companion - just to go out with or to talk with. Question:  After you have your tubes out, is it still tender where the tubing was?  It isn't sore like it was, but it just feels like my muscle is tender.  I'm am sure this will all go away, but being an impatient person, I was hoping for it to be completely gone now. :) My grandaughter, Laura - 6 years old, has been asking a lot of questions about everything - chemo, surgery, why did they do that, what is surgery, what did they cut, etc.  Last night DD came over with her.  DD wanted to see what the incision looked like and Laura did too.  I asked DD what she had told Laura about what was done.  She said she had explained they cut away the cancer and the cancer was in MeMe's "boo-boo" (she started calling boobs this when her son was little - so if he shouted out about a lady's parts, he would say boo-boo and the lady wouldn't know it). So when DD came into the bathroom where there was more light, Laura wanted to see too.  I said I only had one.  She was surprised and asked to make sure there was only one.  I showed her the incision.  Then she opened up her top and said you don't have two of these now.  I said no.  She just said wow.  I know kids keep asking until they are satisfied with the answer given to them, so now she knows.  Whenever I had a scarf on, she wanted me to take it off so she could feel my hair as it started growing in.   After my hair covered my scalp I didn't wear anything on my head.  In my kindergarten class I had one little boy that would rub my hair as he was talking to me.  Kids understand more than we give them credit for most times, funny and honest.
Posts.Title: May 2009 surgery lovinmomma dkhancock1948

Posts.Content: Jun 7, 2009 07:36PM dkhancock1948 wrote: Marcia:  The tenderness is almost gone from where the tubing was.  I get my other tube out tomorrow and the rest of the staples.  Hopefully, the wire-like bra feeling will be gone with the staples and the pinching feeling when the tube is pulled out.  The second tube has been coming out about 1/4 " since last Wednesday.  The nurse said it is stitched in and not to worry, it can't come out.  Anyway, I still put a piece of tape on the tube giving it enough slack.  I don't want to pull it out any farther.  I will have radiation starting the end of June.  The doctor doesn't want any reconstruction until after that.  Right now, I am not planning to have reconstruction.  I'm not that brave to be honest.  My heart and prayers go out to you and anyone who does this.  You are much braver than I am. I hope your weekend went well.  I feel like a baby anymore.  I used to have such a high tolerance for pain, but not anymore.  I want my radiation done so I can go with my life.  It seems like it has been on hold for so long.  I ready for my strength to come back, my neuropathy to be gone and my eyes to be able to see like they were.  Two out of the three may not happen, but I will definitely take that.  I decided this is my summer of healing - from my husband's death on Thanksgiving 2006 and my cancer.  Also, I am going to declutter my house and my mind.  Wish me luck! Lursa:  How are you doing?  Take care.  Debbie
Posts.Title: May 2009 surgery lovinmomma dkhancock1948

Posts.Content: Jun 13, 2009 06:16PM dkhancock1948 wrote: Another question:  Has anyone's eyes changed and seems to keep getting worse after chemo and steroids?  Debbie
Posts.Title: May 2009 surgery lovinmomma dkhancock1948

Posts.Content: Jun 2, 2009 04:01PM dkhancock1948 wrote: I had one tube taken out today plus half of my staples.  The nurse said they would take the other tube out and the rest of the staples next Monday.  She also said I could drive as long as I had no problems with my shoulders, but to still take it easy.  She said with half the staples out, it shouldn't pull as much.  I also found out they took out 5 nodes instead of 2 and 3 were positive.  I need to look and see where certain nodes are.  She said the doctor took out the sentinel node, 3 axillary nodes and 1 pectal node.    It will be wonderful to have the rest of the staples out and the other tube! I just feel bruised now instead of sore where the tubing was. Lursa: How are you doing?  You are in my prayers everytime I say them. My niece-in-law brought me lasagna yesterday evening.  I just put it in the oven, hoping my son would be staying here tonight.  He just came in from work and said he will be going to his fiance's tonight.  I was going to have him take the lasagna out.  I will let it cool a lot before I take it out.  Things you don't think about not being able to do easily until you are in the situation where you need to be careful, especially within two weeks after surgery.  Oh well, all this will pass and in a year, we will all look back and say I did it!  Won't that be grand!!
Posts.Title: May 2009 surgery lovinmomma dkhancock1948

Posts.Content: Jul 16, 2009 12:30AM dkhancock1948 wrote: My depest sympathies go to you and your family.  My prayers are with you.

Posts.Content: Jul 9, 2009 11:32PM dkhancock1948 wrote: Was there someone on this thread that found an enlarged lymph node after surgery was done and rads were done? There is this lady that posted this and has had no response.  She is really anxious. LoriL wrote: Hello ladies! I had bilateral mast 5/28/09 with a negative Sentinel node biopsy at that time. About 2-3 weeks ago I noticed an enlarged lymph node (a little smaller than the size of a marble) but reasoned that it was from the recent surgery. I started rads 3 days ago since my margins were close, and mentioned the lymph node to my Radiation Oncologist today. He believes it is likely from the surgery, but wants it biopsied just to be on the safe side. Now I'm REALLY worried!  My surgeon was certain that he had identified the correct Sentinel node, but I know that they are not 100% accurate. Has anyone out there had a negative Sentinel node biopsy but then found to have cancer in other nodes??? I was able to get in to see my surgeon tomorrow- I'm hoping he will do a needle biopsy right then in the office. I swear, this is almost worrying me more than I was before the initial cancer diagnosis! I have been breathing a sigh of relief as my Oncotype Dx was low and therefore chemo wasn't needed. But, now, my mind is just racing! Help!
Posts.Title: When do I cry? seaofhope one-L

Posts.Content: Jun 30, 2009 10:20PM - edited Jun 30, 2009 10:23PM by dkhancock1948 I felt like I was on a merry-go-round.  I hadn't been for a mammogram in 4 years.  I didn't feel anything.  My husband retired in 2004 and so did the insurance, so I didn't go.  Long story short, he passed away on Thanksgiving in 2006 from major medical problems.  I got a full-time kindergarten teaching job (I graduated from college at 54) and got insurance.  I went for the first mammogram on 10-31.  I was called back my GP nurse on 11-5 telling me I needed a second mammogram.  I went on 11-11 for the second mammogram, 3 core biopies and the needle in the lymphy node.  The radiologiest told me on the 11th that he was sure I had cancer and it was in my lymph node.  I was in shock and didn't cry.  I don't think I cried for quite a while.  It didn't seem real, like it was happening to someone else.  I had chemo first, then a mastectomy and now I am on my radiation.  The doctor could not ell me if they got it all.  I don't think they know.  They took out 6 nodes with 3 being positive.  The radiation doc told me since one of the lymph nodes was a pectoral node, my radiation will cover the entire left breast side, underarm and part of my right side.  She told me that the top and bottom of my left lung, part of my heart and my left rib cage would get some radiation.  I am like you, I don't know.  Yes, I have cried, but I don't remember when.  You are just in shock and you don't know what to do.  I am much older than you, though, so I didn't have those thoughts.  I wish I could help you there.  They have so many more medicines and treatments now that can help you.  Supposedly, everyone has cancer cells going through their bodies.  Why ours decided to stick together in one location and then spread, I don't know.  My daughter was the actual one who told me for sure that I had cancer.  She works as a radiologist tech in the department where I was getting on the tests.  She came to my house the day after my tests and asked if I wanted to find out the results of my tests.  Now I remember, I cried then.  We hugged each other and cried.  I remember now that I did cry.  Do you have someone close you can talk with?  If not, The American Cancer Society has someone that will answer the phone 24 hours a day.  It doesn't matter when you call, they will talk with you.  They can even have someone call you that has been in the same situation as you.  I called one time really late to ask some questions and ended talking for a long time and crying with the other person on the phone. Hope this wasn't too long and maybe some help.  You are in my prayers.  Debbie
Posts.Title: When do I cry? seaofhope one-L

Posts.Content: Jun 30, 2009 09:06PM dkhancock1948 wrote: Angie27:  Congratulations!!!!! What a great feeling that has to be.  I have had my chemo and mastectomy and now will have my 7th rad tomorrow.  I will be so glad to have my life back when all of this is through.  Debbie

Posts.Title: 100 things never to say to a woman who has had a mastectomy: iwannabefree jillyG

Posts.Content: May 25, 2009 04:12AM dkhancock1948 wrote: I live by myself.  My husband passed away on 11-23-2006.  My son works and my daughter works and both have their own families.  I had surgery for a mastectomy on my left side this past Tuesday.  I came home on Wednesday.  I stayed by myself that night.  The PT (in the hospital) showed me how to get up from bed from my right side.  I sleep on the right side of the bed, so I didn't have to change that.  I was allowed to take a shower 48 hours after my surgery.  I had a shower chair ready to use, but didn't need to use it.  I washed my hair with my right hand.  I had three gift certificates given to me, which are great, but I can't drive with the drains in.  I take care of the drains myself, but I only have two.  I am not having any reconstruction, so I can't help you with that.  Things I wished I knew before surgery - I cannot open anything, I needed to stock up on more frozen food.  I cannot bend over easily.  I can not straighten up quickly.  What is normal for the drainage and approximately how long will the drains be in.  It was really interesting to read about the drainage tonight. I wish I knew what was normal after surgery and what is not.  It seems you have questions and it is on the weekends and a holiday.  I have been relatively pain free.  I sit on the right side of my love seat.  I have many pillows propping my left arm up.  I had shingles on the left side of my body in March, two days after my last chemo treatment.  I have the pain that I had before the surgery on my shoulder blade.  (I think it is from the shingles).  My left arm feels tired.  My left shoulder aches a little.  I have neuropathy from the taxol that I received so my toes tingle and are numb and my left hand finger tips tingle and my left thumb is numb.  It would be nice just to have someone here with me - just to even talk with.  I have staples in going from my cleavage to my armpit.  I have steri-strips over the staples.  I feel like I have an extra tight bra on.  Sometimes I have pain where my nipple was, but that was also the nerve where the shingles came out on.  My nipple was extra sensitive with the shingles. I am 60 and heavy, but very independent.  I was fortunate enough to be able to work during my chemo treatment - just walked very slow.  I wasn't nauseated.  Like other people have said, a lot depends on the way you feel and the extent of surgery.   I would say yes to having your friends there to help you out.  It is the little things you don't think about and when you are completely by yourself, it would be nice to have help.  I live in a small town where there are no deliveries to your home. I have learned to scoot my rear towards the edge of my seat before I pushed up with my right hand and arm.  I have to be careful on how much I push, because the muscles on the other side get used, too. I have learned to used my right hand for almost everything.

Posts.Content: Jul 13, 2009 10:23AM dkhancock1948 wrote: Cathi:  You will be in my prayers.  OMG. I feel for you.  I don't care how old your kids get, they are still your babies.  You hurt so much when they are hurt and struggling. You just want to make everything right. It is so hard sometimes to be a parent of grown children.  You have to let them make their own decisions, even though you have your gut feelings.  Thank the Lord, he stopped and that he is gone.  I hear of so many women that stay in situations that are very unhealthy.  I don't know what makes a person snap.  There is a very fine line. Just be there, as I know you are, as a mother, grandmother, friend, helper, listener - all the things that you do as a mother to grown children.  Hold those grandbabies close whenever they let you.  It sounds like you have a great relationship with them.  They are very fortunate. I would like a fairy tale world, too, where everything goes along great all the time.  Unfortunately, we don't live there.  Please know that we all hold you in our arms.  If we could be the army for Jaclyn and her kids, we would be there.  (((((Cathi))))) (((((Jaclyn and kids))))) Debbie
